Infectum.text: 016 Annaqqa i naqqa d kəbʕi, gmaydi i kefayo, kefe manək, məd kaməl u šuġlo ḥaroyo.Zatan məd ṭafi, kfayšo  <kfayši> b dukṯayye gnofəl. Ya gəd foyəš hawxa, gšurṭile, bi ḥarayto gšurṭile, i naqqa d lo nofəl. Gmaydi ak kefaṯṯe, i naqqa d lozəm.

Now then when they want, they take away the stone, one of those stones, when the first work had been over. After (the fire) had already gone out (the stones) remain in their place. (and atuno) either falls down or reamins as it is. (In the latter case) They take it apart, finally they take it apart, if it does not fall. They take away their (own) stones, when it is needed. (2018_07_01_01.2 Arkah, Old Houses:16)

Preterit.text: qayəm ġắlabe qḥīr, w naqqa ḥzelan šrīṭ mə-ḥḏoḏe ʻsie (die Schlange m) wurde sehr böse, und auf einmal sahen wir, wie sie sich auseinanderrollteʼ; 126; 92/22; šriṭ u=ḥawy-awo me-ʕal qḏole d-u=qašo w-azzé ʕabər b-gawe d-u=ṣʕuno ‘This snake untwined from the priest’s neck and crawled into the sandal’; 47/71 u=kurrək ḥəlle u=ḥawyano i=ḥayyaṯe gəšriṭo me bayn dam=maye i=kurfaṯe d dawṣo u=ḥolo ‘the boy saw how this snake crawled from the water to bite the uncle’ (96:60).
Šriṭo i fanerayḏi. My sweater was undone (распутился). (İlyas p.c)
